1/The Chinese Gov just extended an EV subsidy through 2022 for EVs priced below $45,700, but the price restriction doesn't apply if the car has battery swapping.

The gov is helping NIO, which could imply that NIO needs helping.

@long_elon @thoromyr I think this is the correct takeaway

GM provided clarity on its battery cost decline forecast. 
People had speculated about what the starting point was, now we know for sure.

"we will realize a 40% battery cost reduction with our first generation Ultium platform compared with today's Chevrolet Bolt EV."

Landed. 

Reusable Falcon 9 lowered launch costs by an order of magnitude.

Reusable Starship could lower launch costs by another 10-100x. https://t.co/dSRqh3O9Cn
@jackrim1 And I think refurb costs are still declining, which is why I looked at turnaround time. I think that's probably a good proxy.

SpaceX now has two boosters with 9 flights under their belts.
March 2016 Orbital ATK CEO:“It’s still too early to say...of launch rates and refurbishment cost...and so on that relate to reusability – whether it’s going to make economic sense to reuse some of the...launch vehicle" https://t.co/Q9KfPsrLx4
@SnoozeButtonBen Fair point. The left axis assumes 1% of net worth, right axis shows what we think an annual conversion rate would be.
2/This assumes people are willing to spend 1% of their net worth on a crazy experience.

1/ Perfect price discrimination seems like a reasonable strategy until you can get to a price point that unlocks outsized demand, which seems to be at the ~$50,000 mark. https://t.co/8voymwlcGr https://t.co/0SIf6Hc0fm

On the site it says "3X faster than manual picking" What's the context for this claim? Always the same item in the same place?

Hypothesis: A ~28% cost decline per cumulative doubling of battery production is consistent, but Tesla can incorporate industry wide learnings faster than the industry can incorporate learnings from Tesla's in-house efforts.

Time to test it and make falsifiable predictions.

@NatBullard Fair point. Solar company presentations tend to do so.

Everyone models electricity prices as ever increasing, but as solar's share increases ,the marginal cost of electricity production drops. The result is lower realized prices for solar (what it earns during generating hours).

Actual EV production in 2020 was ~2.2 million.

Fun to look back and see what was right/wrong and what changed. Here is a piece we did that was last updated in 2016: https://t.co/oStLP6e8cm

"Based on known battery factory expansion plans through 2020, production will be able to satisfy fewer than 1.3 million 200-mile EVs."
@YCuiARK It's going to be very hard to stand out from the crowd.😛😛 https://t.co/wLMvBNsVL9
@YCuiARK Yea it looks particularly good in the rearview mirror 😛 https://t.co/rbQleKhfHs

3/When ARK first modeled EV price parity we assumed a 200 mile range EV because that accommodated something like ~90%+ of trips. Now we think 350 mile range is needed to satisfy most consumer purchasing behavior (not driving behavior).
